questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with hip pain and limping. He has a history of obesity and is at risk for slipped capital femoral epiphysis. What radiographic view would be most appropriate to assess his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Frog Leg Lateral View

 

Explanation:

The frog leg lateral view is specifically used to evaluate slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

 

Dunn’s View (Option A):

  • Radiographic projection of the hip that demonstrates and examines the hip joint, femoral head, acetabulum, and particularly the relationship of the femoral head and acetabulum.
  • Indication:
    • Femoroacetabular impingement (FAI)
    • Femoral head-neck asphericity
  • Positioning:
    • Patient is supine with the hip joint flexed 90° and abducted 20°.
    • Beam is focused on the midpoint between the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and pubic symphysis.

 

 

Frog Leg Lateral View: (Option B)

  • Indication: Used in the assessment of:
    • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
    • Perthes disease
  • Procedure:
    • The patient is supine with the affected limb flexed at the knee approximately 30° to 40°, and the hip is abducted 45°. The beam is focused midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis.
    • If it is a bilateral examination, both knees are to rest on sponges, giving the appearance of "frog legs."

Danelius-Miller View: (Option C)

  • Indication: To detect abnormalities in the hip:
    • Dislocation
    • Pathologic condition
    • Suspected fracture
  • Procedure:
    • Supine, symptomatic hip internally rotated 15-20° and asymptomatic hip 45° abduction, knee 45° flexed.
    • Central ray is positioned horizontally and perpendicular to the femoral neck.

Clement’s Nakayama View: (Option D)

  • Modified axiolateral view of the hip.
  • Highly specialized lateral projection utilized on patients with bilateral femoral fractures or patients unable to mobilize due to postoperative requirements.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with a history of alcohol use disorder presents with hip pain. An MRI of the hip reveals a smooth, linear geographic signal abnormality that is concave to the articular surface. There are central fat signals and both low- and high-signal demarcation lines. What condition is most likely indicated by the MRI findings in this patient?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Avascular necrosis
 

Explanation:

The described MRI findings, including the smooth, linear geographic signal abnormality and the double line sign, are characteristic of avascular necrosis, especially in the context of this patient’s alcohol use disorder.

 

Indications of MRI in hip joint:

  • Detecting occult hip fractures,
  • Stress or insufficiency fractures,
  • Avascular necrosis,
  • Labral and tendon pathologies,
  • Identifying neoplasms and infections.

 

Avascular necrosis (AVN)

  • The typical MRI appearance shows a smooth, linear geographic signal abnormality, concave to the articular surface, featuring a central fat signal and both low- and high-signal demarcation lines known as the Double line sign or Geographic line. (Option B)
  • Marrow edema may be present, and subchondral collapse or fracture can eventually occur.
  • X-ray: Crescent sign (Subchondral collapse)

 

Advantages

Disadvantages
  • Non-invasive, no radiation
  • Clear, detailed soft tissue images
  • Captures images from multiple angles
  • Helps detect cancer spread and guides treatment
  • Expensive
  • Metal implants can be affected by the MRI magnet
  • Gantry is narrower than in CT
  • Claustrophobic patients may feel discomfort in the enclosed machine
  • Patient must remain still, dynamic test not possible
  • Noisy
  • Gadolinium contrast is not recommended for use in pregnant women.

 

Contraindications:
  • Cardiac Implantable Electronic Devices (CIED)
  • Cerebral Artery Aneurysm Clips
  • Implantable Neurostimulation Systems
  • Catheters with Metallic Components (e.g., Swan-Ganz Catheter)
  • Magnetic Dental Implants
  • Metallic Fragments (Bullets, Pellets, Shrapnel)
  • Drug Infusion Pumps
  • Cochlear Implants
  • Tissue Expander
  • Artificial Limbs
  • Hearing Aids
  • Piercing

 

Osteoarthritis (Option A) is characterized by joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis.

 

Osteomyelitis (Option C) is a bone infection that typically shows irregular signal patterns and edema on MRI.

  • The smooth and linear abnormalities seen here are characteristic of avascular necrosis.

 

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option D) features synovitis and joint effusion, leading to erosions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with knee pain and a suspected patellar fracture after a fall. The physician orders imaging to evaluate the fracture. Which of the following radiographic views would not be appropriate for assessing a patellar fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) AP Knee View

 

Explanation:

  • The anteroposterior (AP) view of the knee provides a general overview of the knee joint and surrounding structures, making it suitable for assessing dislocations, fractures, and osteoarthritis.
  • However, it does not offer the detailed visualization necessary for specific patellar evaluation.

 

Skyline Merchant View (Option A):

  • Superior-inferior projection of the patella.
  • Indications:
    • Patellar fracture
    • Patellar subluxation
    • Patellofemoral joint disease
  • Patient position: The patient is supine on the table with both knees flexed at roughly 45°.

 

Sunrise View (Option B):

  • Here, the patella appears to be rising over the horizon.
  • The radiograph is taken with the X-ray beam tangential to the patella parallel to the long axis of the lower extremity.
  • Indication:
    • Knee osteoarthritis (OA)
    • Patellar fracture
    • Patellar subluxation
  • Patient Position: The patient is prone, with the knee flexed 115p with a central beam directed toward the patella with approximately 15p cephalad angulation.

Horizontal Beam Lateral View (Option D) is particularly useful for evaluating patellar fractures because it allows visualization of the knee joint while minimizing patient movement.

  • This view can reveal the presence of joint effusion and fat pad displacement, which may indicate an underlying patellar fracture or associated knee pathology.

questions.text:
Match the following:

 


	
		
			
			View
			
			
			Indication 
			
		
		
			
			1. Scaphoid View
			
			
			A. Thumb trapeziometacarpal arthritis.
			
		
		
			
			2. Carpal Tunnel View
			
			
			B. Scaphoid fracture.
			
		
		
			
			3. Clenched Fist View
			
			
			C. Fractures of the hook of the hamate
			
		
		
			
			4. Brewerton’s View
			
			
			D. Widening of the scapholunate interval.
			
		
		
			
			5. Robert’s View
			
			
			E. Collateral ligament avulsion fracture.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1B,2C,3D,4E,5A

 

Explanation:

Scaphoid View:

  • Performed with the wrist in ulnar deviation to free the scaphoid from bony superimposition.
  • Although performed PA, the view is often referred to as an AP view.

 

Carpal Tunnel View:

  • Axial projection to demonstrate medial and lateral prominences and concavity.
  • The wrist dorsiflexed approximately 135°, lifting carpals and metacarpals away from the cassette.
  • Indications: Used to investigate fractures of the hook of hamate, pisiform, and trapezium.

 

Clenched Fist View:

  • Clenched fist view is an additional projection often performed bilaterally to evaluate suspected widening of the scapholunate interval.
  • It is a functional view that requires the patient to clench both hands.
  • Signet ring sign in the scaphoid is indicative of scapholunate dissociation.

Brewerton’s View:

  • Tangential view of the metacarpal heads.
  • Metacarpophalangeal joint is flexed to 65p with the dorsum of the proximal phalanx.
  • Indication:
    • Visualize collateral ligament avulsion fracture.
    • Diagnosis of arthritic changes.

 

Robert’s View

  • True AP view of the thumb taken with the wrist in maximal pronation with the dorsum of the thumb parallel to the table in which the beam is centered on the trapeziometacarpal joint.
  • Indication: Thumb trapeziometacarpal arthritis
  • Bett's (Gedda's view) view is taken with the hand pronated 30p and the imaging beam directed obliquely in a distal to proximal direction and centered over the trapeziometacarpal joint.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with shoulder pain after a sports injury. The physician suspects an anterior glenohumeral dislocation and orders imaging. Which imaging view is best for assessing Hill-Sachs defects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Stryker’s Notch View

 

Explanation:

Stryker’s Notch View is ideal for evaluating posterior humeral injuries and identifying Hill-Sachs defects after anterior dislocation.

 

Scapular Y View (Option C):

  • Scapula appears laterally in a clear 'Y' shape.
  • Acromion and coracoid processes form the upper arms of the 'Y'.
  • Humeral head, if intact, is superimposed at the base of the 'Y'.

  • Indications:
    • Suspected shoulder dislocations.
    • Scapula fractures.
    • Degenerative changes.
    • Useful for viewing the coracoid and acromion processes.

 

Stryker’s Notch View (Option D):

  • Specialized projection of the shoulder aimed at assessing the posterior humerus.
  • Indications:
    • Post-anterior glenohumeral dislocation.
    • Assessing for Hill-Sachs defects.

 

 

Coyle’s View (Option B):

  • Also called the Trauma Oblique View of the Elbow.
  • Indications:
    • Used for suspected radial head fractures.
    • Elbow dislocation.
    • Visualize capitellum of the distal humerus.
    • Effective for patients unable to fully extend their arms.
  • Patient Position:
    • Patient sits with the elbow flexed at 90° with the medial border of the palm and forearm kept in contact with the tabletop.
    • Shoulder, elbow, and wrist aligned in the same horizontal plane and the thumb points upwards.
  • The beam angled 45° towards the humerus.

 

Zanca’s View (Option A) is used to examine the acromioclavicular joint (AC) and is not intended to assess Hill-Sachs defects related to shoulder dislocations.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with severe shoulder pain after a fall. She is unable to abduct her arm and has a suspected posterior shoulder dislocation. The physicin orders imaging to confirm the diagnosis. Which imaging view is most appropriate for diagnosing her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Velpeau View

 

Explanation:

Velpeau View is specifically used for diagnosing posterior shoulder dislocations, especially when the arm cannot be abducted.

 

Axial View (Option A):

  • Purpose:
    • Assess suspected shoulder dislocations.
    • Evaluate proximal humerus pathology.
    • Detects glenohumeral articular surface abnormalities.
  • Procedure: Use a specialized glenohumeral joint projection with a 5-15° degree angulation towards the patient’s elbow.

Velpeau View (Option B):

  • Indications:
    • Performed on patients with a shoulder sling (Velpeau bandage) in place.
    • Often used in post-operative or post-reduction cases where the patient cannot abduct the arm.
    • Particularly useful for diagnosing posterior shoulder dislocations.
  • Procedure:
    • Performed with the patient in an erect position with a 30° backward lean with an x-ray tube straight up and down, centered at the glenohumeral joint.
    • Demonstrates the anterior and posterior humeral head and the glenoid fossa clearly.

Grashey’s View (Option C):

  • Shoulder AP glenoid view is also known as a true AP or a ‘Grashey view’ (AP Oblique).
  • Indications:
    • Used to assess integrity of the glenohumeral joint.
    • Also to inspect the glenoid rim and the articular surface of the humerus.
    • Bankart lesion.
    • Post-dislocation-relocation.
    • Proximal migration of the humerus.
    • General joint space assessment.
    • Post-operative evaluation.

Procedure: Patient is preferably erect, parallel to the image receptor and is rotated 30-45° toward the affected side to display the glenohumeral joint space.


Serendipity View (Option D) focuses on the sternoclavicular joints and is not appropriate for diagnosing shoulder dislocations, especially in the context of this patient's injury.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male athlete presents with severe pain and swelling in his right shoulder after falling during a basketball game. The physician suspects an acromioclavicular joint injury and orders an X-ray. Which imaging view is best for evaluating the acromioclavicular joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Zanca’s View

 

Explanation:

Zanca's View is specifically designed to evaluate the acromioclavicular joint.

 

Cephalic Tilt View (Option A):

  • Indication: for visualizing the clavicle and in determining the angulation of fractures and dislocations.

Serendipity view (Option B):

  • Indication: Used to visualize the sternoclavicular joints and medial 1/3 of the clavicles for fractures or dislocation.
  • Procedure: 40° cephalic tilt view of the sternoclavicular joints with the patient in a supine position.

Zanca’s View (Option D):

  • Indication: for examining the acromioclavicular joint (AC).
  • Procedure: erect anteroposterior view with the beam directed at the AC joint with 10° of cephalic tilt.

 

Westpoint View (Option C):

Indication: Used to detect anterior glenoid abnormalities, such as Bankart Lesions, in patients with a history of traumatic shoulder instability.

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman with a history of breast cancer is suspected to have bone metastases. The oncologist opts for an MRI scan to confirm the diagnosis. What is the primary reason MRI is chosen over other imaging modalities in this pregnant patient?

choices.text: MRI provides a more detailed assessment of bone metastases.
MRI does not use ionizing radiation, making it safer during pregnancy.
MRI is faster than CT in staging bone metastases.
MRI provides more specific metabolic information than nuclear scans.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) MRI does not use ionising radiation, making it safer during pregnancy.
 

Explanation:

  • MRI is preferred in pregnant patients because it does not involve ionizing radiation, which can be harmful to the developing fetus.
  • This makes it a safer option compared to CT scans or nuclear imaging, which use radiation.

 

MRI in bone tumors

  • MRI is more accurate for tumor measurements, radiation planning, and resection planning, particularly when using contrast.

 

Advantages:

  • Provides high spatial resolution images and excellent tissue discrimination across multiple planes.
  • Features useful for lesion characterization include:
    • Precise anatomical location and extent of the lesion.
    • Extent of perilesional edema in both bone marrow and soft tissue.
    • Degree of extraosseous extension and involvement of neurovascular structures and joints.
    • Signal characteristics that help identify specific tissue components within lesions.
  • MRI is the preferred investigation for suspected spinal cord compression due to pathological vertebral body fractures.
  • MRI does not use ionizing radiation, and it is ideal for detecting bone metastases in pregnant women. (Option B)

 

Dynamic Contrast Enhancement:

  • Gadolinium-enhanced MRI distinguishes between solid and necrotic/cystic components in lesions.
  • Dynamic contrast enhancement can differentiate higher-grade lesions, which enhance more rapidly, from lower-grade ones.

 

Whole-Body MRI:

  • Sometimes used for staging bone tumors, especially in children (e.g., Ewing sarcoma).
  • Involves acquiring wide-field images using sensitive sequences (e.g., STIR, DIXON, diffusion-weighted imaging) to detect metastatic lesions from head to toe.
  • Valuable for identifying small intramedullary bone metastases that may not be visible on CT and nuclear imaging, avoiding ionizing radiation.

 

Detailed assessment of bone metastases is an advantage, but the key reason for choosing MRI is safety, not detail (Option C).

 

CT is typically faster, but the priority in pregnancy is avoiding radiation, not speed (Option A).

 

Nuclear scans offer better metabolic information, but MRI is selected for its safety profile in this scenario (Option D).

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents with chronic osteomyelitis of the Femur after an open fracture. He experiences persistent drainage from a sinus tract. MRI is given below. What is the significance of the marked sign in this patient?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Represents the reactive hypervascular granulation tissue surrounding a necrotic cavity
Confirms the presence of a tumor-like lesion

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Represents the reactive hypervascular granulation tissue surrounding a necrotic cavity

 

Explanation:

  • The given image shows the Penumbra sign. It indicates the presence of a central abscess filled with pus surrounded by a thin rim of enhanced hypervascular granulation tissue.
  • On MRI, the abscess appears to have a low signal intensity on T1-weighted images and a high signal intensity on T2-weighted and STIR images, with enhancement after contrast administration.
  • This sign is specific for intraosseous or subperiosteal abscesses in chronic osteomyelitis.

 

Acute osteomyelitis
 
  • MRI can reveal early signs of acute osteomyelitis, such as bone marrow edema, within 1-2 days of infection onset
  • In acute osteomyelitis, the typical high signal intensity of fatty bone marrow on T1-weighted MRI images decreases, reflecting congestion from fluid and pus.
  • In contrast, fluid-sensitive sequences and post-contrast images display high signal intensity, indicating the presence of edema and inflammation.

Chronic osteomyelitis
 

MRI findings in chronic osteomyelitis can reveal:

  • Abscesses and sinus tracts.
  • Sequestra (Necrotic bone fragments appear as low signal intensity areas on T1, T2, and STIR sequences and do not show enhancement.)
  • Thickened periosteum and cloacae.
  • Granulation tissue, soft tissue inflammation & sinus tracks exhibit T1 hypointensity, T2 and STIR hyperintensity, and enhancement after contrast administration.
 

Penumbra sign:

  • It indicates low signal intensity in intraosseous and subperiosteal abscesses, with high signal intensity in surrounding fluid-sensitive sequences.
  • It features a thin enhancing rim of hypervascular granulation tissue around a central low-intensity pus-filled cavity. (Option B)

 

Cloacae are drainage channels for pus but are not represented by the penumbra sign, which specifically highlights granulation tissue around an abscess. (Option A)

 

The penumbra sign is not indicative of tumors, which have different imaging characteristics. It specifically relates to abscess formation in chronic infections. (Option C)

 

The penumbra sign is associated with chronic osteomyelitis, not acute inflammation. (Option D)

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents with pain and swelling in her right elbow following a minor fall. She received a deep tissue massage shortly after the injury. Examination reveals tenderness and limited motion in the elbow. The lateral radiograph of the right elbow joint is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Myositis ossificans traumatica

 

Explanation:

  • Lateral radiograph of the right elbow showing distal ossification, combined with the history of trauma and symptoms, strongly indicate myositis ossificans traumatica.
  • This condition can develop following injury to ligaments, tendons, periosteum or bones and is often exacerbated by improper treatment such as deep tissue massage.

 

Myositis ossificans (MO)

  • Heterotopic bone formation within a muscle or any other type of soft tissue (tendons, ligament, fascia and connective tissue).
  • 2 Types:
    • Myositis Ossificans Traumatica (MOT): Acquired
    • Myositis Ossificans Progressiva (MOP): Congenital

 

Myositis Ossificans Traumatica (MOT)

  • Causes:
    • Ill-advised massage (M/c cause): Vigorous and improper massage following trauma
    • Trauma: Injury to muscles, ligaments, tendons, periosteum, and bones results in bleeding and eventual myositis.
    • Simple blow or repeated minor trauma: Repeated and constant soft tissue damage can result in myositis.
    • Dislocations and avulsion injuries: More prone to develop myositis due to violent periosteal stripping and muscle damage.
    • Common in children: Periosteum is loosely attached to bones (commonly around the elbow joint).
    • High incidence in patients with neuronal damage: Common in head injury patients and paraplegics.
  • Pathology:
    • Structures Involved: Muscles (M/c), fascia, tendon, and periosteum.
    • Muscles Commonly Affected: Brachialis anticus, quadratus femoris and adductor muscles of the thigh.
    • Sites Affected:
      • Elbow joint common in young athletes
      • Ankle joint (known as Footballer’s ankle)
      • Knee (known as Pellegrini-Stieda disease)
      • Shoulder
      • Hip
    • Changes: Peculiar alteration within the ground substance of the connective tissue associated with undifferentiated connective tissue proliferation.
    • If the periosteum is involved: Subperiosteal hematoma undergoes proliferation and metaplasia, resulting in bone formation.
  • Classification (Based on its location):
    • Hematoma is a prerequisite in all three cases.
  1. Extra-osseous
  2. Periosteal: Beneath the periosteum
  3. Paraosteal
  • Clinical Features:
    • Acute stages:
      • Pain
      • Swelling
      • Loss of movement
      • Tenderness on examination
    • Chronic stages:
      • No pain
      • Bony lump may be palpated




 

  • Radiological findings:
    • Active myositis: Fluffy margins of the bone mass.
    • Mature myositis: Trabeculated bone with well-defined margins.
  • Biopsy:
    • Ackerman zone phenomenon:
  1. Central highly cellular area
  2. Zone of fibroblastic tissue
  3. Zone of mature, well-oriented bone
  • Treatment:
    • Massage following injury is strictly prohibited.
    • Acute stages:
      • Immobilization
      • Medications (diphosphonates, calcitonin, NSAIDs)
      • Active physiotherapy (passive stretching is avoided)
    • Chronic stages:
      • Surgery is the treatment of choice (soft tissue release, excision of bony spur).

 

Osteosarcoma (Option A) typically presents with a longer duration of symptoms, including bone pain and possibly systemic signs.

  • The radiographic findings usually show aggressive bone destruction and distinct patterns, such as "sunburst" configurations, which do not match the distal ossification pattern observed in myositis ossificans.


 

Aggressive fibromatosis (Option B) presents as a firm, painless mass, often associated with irregular underlying bone erosion, particularly in the head and neck region.

  • This presentation contrasts with the acute pain and swelling observed in myositis ossificans, which is characterized by specific radiographic findings of ossification.



 

Osteochondritis dissecans (Option C) (OCD) typically presents as a focal subchondral bone abnormality affecting the knee, characterized by specific radiographic stages that show varying degrees of bone and cartilage involvement.

  • This presentation differs from myositis ossificans, which is primarily associated with trauma and shows distinct ossification patterns rather than the staged defects seen in OCD.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with shoulder pain and weakness after a fall while playing basketball. He reports difficulty lifting his arm when trying to reach overhead. On examination, there is weakness in abduction and external rotation of the shoulder. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) MRI

 

Explanation:

  • In the given scenario, the presence of weakness in abduction and external rotation suggests a rotator cuff injury.
  • MRI is the gold standard investigation for rotator cuff injuries and reveals any discontinuity in the supraspinatus tendon, which is indicative of a tear.

 

MRI shoulder (rotator cuff injuries)

  • A rotational cuff tear refers to a disruption of tendon fibers.
  • Most often occurs in the supraspinatus tendon, near its insertion or 8 to 15 mm above the greater tuberosity (referred to as the critical zone).

Normal Image of rotator cuff

Partial Thickness Tear
  • Appears as a focal area of fiber discontinuity filled with fluid signal on T2W images. (Option D)
  • Fat-suppressed sequences enhance the visibility of the fluid-filled tendon defect.
  • Surface fraying and changes in tendon caliber.

Full Thickness Tear
  • Appears as a focal discontinuity in the tendon, extending from the articular to the bursal surface. (Option C)
  • Seen as fluid signal intensity on T2-weighted (T2W) images.
  • Fluid may be present in the subacromial-subdeltoid (SASD) bursa and joint space.
  • Secondary signs include tendon retraction, superior translation of the humeral head, and muscle atrophy, can be seen.


 

Ultrasound (Option A) is a very good modality for the evaluation of the rotator cuff but has limitations due to the skill needed for getting appropriate images and the difficulty in differentiating chronic tears and tendinopathies.

 

CT (Option C) has a limited role in the evaluation of rotator cuff injuries and is used to detect muscle atrophy and fatty degeneration.

 

X-ray (Option D) is the first modality of evaluation and shows humeral migration to determine a diagnosis between acute and chronic tears but will not show the exact injury of the rotator cuff.

questions.text:
In the given MRI image of the knee identify the posterior cruciate ligament.



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) b

Explanation:

The posterior cruciate ligament is marked as “b” in the image.

 

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) provides detailed images of the soft tissue structures, such as menisci, ligaments, and cartilage, as well as the bone marrow in the knee.

Structure

MRI appearance

The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL)

(Option D)

Appears as a straight band parallel to the intercondylar roof in a sagittal MRI.

The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL)

Appears as a homogenous hypointense structure and is supported by the anterior and posterior meniscofemoral ligaments.

Menisci

The menisci are seen as low-intensity structures in the MRI appearing as a “triangle” or “wedge” in the coronal view and like a “bowtie” in the sagittal view.

Bone cortex (Option C)

Appears as a hypointense lining of the bone.

Patella (Option A)

When the knee is fully extended, the normal patella is positioned laterally in relation to the trochlea.

choices.text: The presence of edema and hyperintense signal suggests a complete ACL tear
An ACL angle greater than 15° indicates a partial rupture.
The "Empty Notch Sign" observed on MRI indicates an ACL avulsion injury.
A hyperintense signal in the ACL with a normal angle suggests a complete tear rather than a partial tear.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The "Empty Notch Sign" observed on MRI indicates an ACL avulsion injury.

 

Explanation:

The given MRI shows an ACL tear, therefore the "Empty Notch Sign" indicates avulsion at the femoral attachment site.

 

Anterior cruciate ligament injury
 
  • Edema and hyperintense signal on T2 or fat-saturated PD images.
  • Visible tear or abnormal contour, often in the middle portion (midsubstance) of the ligament.
  • ACL fibers appear less steep than the intercondylar (Blumensaat) line; ACL angle >15° suggests rupture.
  • Empty Notch Sign: Fluid signal at the femoral attachment site in the intercondylar notch, indicating avulsion. (Option C)
  • Partial Tear: Normal ACL angle but with a hyperintense signal suggests partial rupture rather than complete tear.
  • A torn ACLstump will give a "Bell-hammer Sign.” usually seen in partial tear
  • Gap Sign: Fluid or gap between the medial lateral femoral condyle and mid-ACL, seen in isolated posterolateral bundle tears.

Posterior cruciate ligament injury
 
  • PCL often remains intact (~70%) despite partial or complete disruption.
  • Enlarged and swollen PCL with an AP diameter >7 mm in the vertical portion on sagittal images suggests a tear.
  • A posterior tibial shift of more than 2-3 mm in the mid-medial compartment indicates injury

 

  • Edema and hyperintense signals can indicate a tear, they do not definitively diagnose a complete tear without further evaluation. (Option A)
  • An ACL angle greater than 15° suggests a complete rupture, not a partial rupture. (Option B)
  • A hyperintense signal with a normal angle typically indicates a partial tear. (Option D)

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female presents with chronic knee pain and occasional joint swelling and clicking in the joint. She reports no history of trauma. The MRI findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Horizontal meniscal tear with parameniscal cyst

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Horizontal meniscal tear with parameniscal cyst

 

Explanation:

  • Horizontal meniscal tears are common in degenerative conditions and often seen in patients over 40 years old, typically running parallel to the tibial plateau.
  • In this case, the MRI shows a horizontal tear in the posterior horn of the medial Q meniscus, a common site for such tears.
  • The fluid collection adjacent to the tear is a hallmark of a parameniscal cyst, often associated with complete horizontal tears, due to communication with joint fluid.
  • The menisci are fibrocartilaginous, crescent-shaped structures between the femoral condyles and tibial plateaus.
  • They stabilize the knee by absorbing shock and distributing the load.
  • On MRI, the menisci appear as hypointense structures (dark) across all sequences.
  • On sagittal images: "Bow-tie" shape peripherally or opposing triangles centrally.
  • On coronal images: Triangular or wedge-shaped
  • The anterior and posterior horns of the lateral meniscus are typically of equal size.
  • In contrast, on the medial side, the posterior horn of the medial meniscus is larger than the anterior horn.
  • Meniscal cysts are caused by encysted synovial fluid, often as a result of a meniscal tear.
  • If these cysts extend beyond the meniscus’s margins, they are referred to as parameniscal cysts.
  • Meniscal tears are classified as horizontal, longitudinal vertical, or radial based on tear direction.
  • Common causes include trauma and degeneration.

 

Meniscal tear

Key Characteristics on MRI

Horizontal Tear

Horizontal line of high signal intensity; involves articular surfaces and can cause parameniscal cysts.

Longitudinal Tear (Option B)

Vertically oriented tear; runs parallel to the meniscus axis and often involves the red zone. Usually traumatic in origin.

Radial Tear (Option C)

Perpendicular to the meniscus, disrupts hoop strength, seen as truncation of free edge, does not form parameniscal cysts.

Bucket Handle Tear (Option D)

Longitudinal tear with fragment migration; shows a "double PCL" sign or displaced fragment in the intercondylar notch.

  • Symptoms: Joint pain, clicking, joint effusion, locking, and pseudo-locking from hamstring spasms.
  • Diagnosis:
    • MRI is the investigation of choice, showing tear morphology and associated injuries.
    • Joint arthroscopy is the gold standard investigation as it can detect the morphological changes in the meniscus.
  • Treatment: Focuses on meniscal preservation with repair, meniscectomy, or transplantation only if symptoms such as locking or displacement occur.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with progressive back pain, weight loss, and leg weakness. There is tenderness over the thoracic spine, raising suspicion of a spinal tumor. What is the investigation of choice to evaluate for a spinal tumor?

choices.text: CT scan of the thoracic spine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) MRI of the thoracic spine

 

Explanation:

MRI is the investigation of choice for spinal tumors because it provides excellent delineation of vertebral body marrow, allowing detection of both primary and metastatic disease.

 

MRI Spine is the investigation of choice in:

  1. Intervertebral Disc Diseases:
  • Bulge: symmetric disc extension beyond the interspace most commonly seen in lumbar spine > cervical spine.
  • Protrusion: Asymmetric disc extension beyond the interspace.
  • Extrusion: Extreme disc extension beyond the interspace.
  • Sequestration: A fully separated disc fragment.
     
  • Postoperative Back Pain:
    • Detecting residual disc material.
    • Identifying epidural hematomas or abscesses.
    • Diagnosing postoperative discitis.
  • Spinal Tumors:
    • Excellent delineation of vertebral body marrow allows detection of both primary and metastatic disease with high sensitivity T1-weighted sequence.


 

  • Spinal Trauma:
    • Spinal cord injury
    • Epidural hematomas
  • Traumatic disc herniation
  • Detecting soft tissue injuries (e.g., ligamentous tears) in the acute stage.


 

X-ray of the thoracic spine (Option A): Limited to assessing bony structures and cannot evaluate soft tissue or marrow changes.

 

CT scan of the thoracic spine (Option B): While good for bony lesions, it lacks the soft tissue detail necessary to identify tumors and their effects on surrounding structures.

 

PET scan (Option D): Useful for metabolic activity and staging but does not provide detailed anatomical information about the spine and tumors.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents to the hospital after sustaining multiple fractures in a motorcycle accident. Within 36 hours of the trauma, he develops tachycardia, fever, confusion, and a PaO of 55 mm Hg. A chest X-ray is taken and is shown below. He has petechial rashes noted on his conjunctiva and neck, and his platelet count is 120,000/mm³. What is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acute respiratory distress syndrome

 

Explanation:

The presence of tachycardia, fever, confusion, low PaO, petechial rashes, and thrombocytopenia, along with the characteristic "snowstorm" appearance on the chest X-ray, indicates Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), commonly associated with fat embolism after multiple fractures.

 

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)/Fat Embolism
  • Defined as post-traumatic distress syndrome occurring within 72 hours of skeletal trauma.
  • Typically manifests within 24-48 hours but can be delayed.
  • Dreaded complication, often associated with multiple fractures, major bone fractures, pelvic fractures, and multisystem injuries (chest, abdomen, head injuries).
  • Affects 10-45% of multiple fracture cases with 11% mortality.

Etiology

  • Young adults (20-30 years): Long bone fractures
  • Elderly: Pelvic fractures
  • Iatrogenic cause: Occurs after reamed intramedullary (IM) nailing of the femur.

Sources of Fat

It can be from 2 sources:

  1. Mechanical theory: Fat from bone marrow (most accepted).
  2. Biochemical theories:
  1. Obstructive theory: Agglutination of chylomicrons in plasma acts as emboli (less accepted).
  2. Toxic theory: Free fatty acids destroy pneumocytes, causing ARDS.

Pathogenesis

Following injury, fat from bone marrow or platelet agglutination enters injured vessels and travels as emboli, leading to various clinical manifestations.

Gurd’s Criteria For Fat Embolism

Major criteria:

  1. Axillary and subconjunctival petechiae
  2. PaO <60 mm Hg
  3. CNS depression

Minor criteria:

  1. Pulse >110/min
  2. Pyrexia >38.5°C
  3. Retinal embolism
  4. Fat in urine
  5. Reduced platelet count
  6. Increased ESR
  7. Fat globules in sputum

Diagnostic criteria: At least 1 major criterion + 4 minor criteria required for diagnosis.

Investigations
  • Chest X-ray: Snowstorm appearance (pathognomonic).
  • PaO <60 mm Hg.
  • Platelet count <1.5 lakhs.
  • ECG: Prominent S-wave.
  • Gurd test: Isolation of fat emboli from the blood.
  • Other lab findings: Anemia, hypocalcemia.
  • CT scan and MRI: Assess severity.

Diagnostic triad (TPR mnemonic)
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • PaO <60 mm Hg
  • Rashes

Management

  • Respiratory support: Oxygen or ventilator support to restore PaO.
  • Drug therapy:
    • Steroids: Reduce lung inflammation and improve gas exchange.
    • Heparin: Lipolytic and antiplatelet agent.
    • Low molecular weight dextran: Increases plasma volume.
    • Antibiotics and other supportive care.
  • Definitive fracture treatment: Early fixation to prevent worsening.

 

Pulmonary edema (Option A) is characterized by specific X-ray findings such as enlargement of the vascular pedicle and cephalization of pulmonary vessels, which are not present in this case

  • Additionally, the combination of petechial rashes and low platelet count supports the diagnosis of ARDS.

 

Aspiration pneumonia (Option B) is characterized by acute onset following inhalation of oropharyngeal or gastric contents (in unconscious/patient with loss of cough reflex), typically presenting with alveolar infiltrates in dependent lung areas on chest X-ray

  • However, in this case, the distinct presentation of multiple fractures and systemic symptoms, along with the "snowstorm" appearance on the X-ray, is more indicative of ARDS, rather than aspiration pneumonia.

 

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (Option D) (TRALI) presents with acute, noncardiogenic pulmonary edema and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray, distinguishing it from ARDS, which can have a broader range of causes and may not be directly linked to transfusion events.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with concerns about foot deformities. An anteroposterior radiograph of the feet is taken, as shown below. The child also exhibits episodes of painful swelling in the shoulders and neck, leading to difficulty in movement. What is the most likely diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva

 

Explanation:

The child’s foot deformities, including symmetrical first-toe malformations seen on X-ray, episodes of painful swelling in the shoulders and neck, and difficulty in movement indicate Fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva (FOH).

 

Myositis (Fibrodysplasia) ossificans progressiva:

  • Extremely rare genetic connective tissue disorder affecting all the skeletal muscles.
  • Characterized by heterotopic ossification.
  • Affects ligaments, tendons, and skeletal muscles, leading to joint immobility.

 

  • Age Group: typically appears in early childhood, often before age 6, and progresses throughout life.
  • Causes:
    • Most cases are sporadic, autosomal dominant patterns.
    • Caused by a change in the ACVR1 gene in the bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) signaling pathway.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Skeletal Malformations:
      • Most common: shortened great toes with malformed distal first metatarsal and missing or malformed first phalanx
  • Hallux valgus
  • Microdactyly
  • Clinodactyly of the fifth finger
  • Proximal medial tibial osteochondromas
  • Cervical vertebrae malformations
  • First Sign: Firm tender swellings (flare-ups) on certain parts of the body, especially the back, neck, and shoulders.
  • These soft tissue swellings mature through a cartilage-to-bone (endochondral) pathway to form mature heterotopic bone.
  • Pain and stiffness often occur in these areas.
  • Progression:
    • Involves deformities of the spine, hands, and feet.
    • Life expectancy decreases, with the most common cause of death being lung disease.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Commonly misdiagnosed; examination of toes for short great toes can aid diagnosis.
    • Confirmed through clinical evaluation and sequencing of the ACVR1 gene.
  • Treatment:
    • No effective treatment.
    • Short-term high-dose corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) can manage flare-ups but should not be used frequently.
    • Mast cell inhibitors, NSAIDs, amino bisphosphonates, and COX-2 inhibitors for flare-up management.

 

Soft tissue sarcoma (Option A): The absence of a palpable mass and the specific symptoms of toe malformations and joint swelling do not align with the typical presentation of soft tissue sarcomas, which usually present as enlarging lumps.

 

Progressive osseous heteroplasia (Option B) (POH) characterized byabnormal bone growth starting on the skin's surface and does not include the specific toe malformations typical of FOP.

  • Additionally, POH typically does not present with painful swellings or episodes of inflammation, making the symptoms, in this case, more aligned with FOP.

Aggressive juvenile fibromatosis (Option C) is characterized by fibroblast overgrowth in connective tissues, leading to soft tissue masses.

  • However, it does not present with the hallmark toe malformations or the painful swelling and heterotopic ossification typical of FOP, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.
